That's a great approach! By creating a detailed and organized character database in Ulysses, you'll be able to keep track of your characters' traits, relationships, and motivations, which will help you develop a more cohesive and engaging story.

Remember to be thorough and detailed in your character development. The more you know about your characters, the more realistic and believable they'll be to your readers. Don't be afraid to add new headers or subheaders as needed, and feel free to experiment with different character development techniques to find what works best for you.

Some additional tips to consider:

* **Make your characters relatable**: Give your characters flaws, fears, and motivations that readers can identify with. This will help readers become invested in their journey and care about what happens to them.
* **Create character contradictions**: Make your characters complex by giving them contradictory traits or motivations. For example, a brave warrior who's afraid of heights or a kind-hearted healer who's struggling with anger issues.
* **Develop character backstories**: Give your characters rich backstories that inform their motivations and actions. This will help you understand why they make certain decisions and behave in certain ways.
* **Use character development to reveal world-building**: Use your characters' experiences and perspectives to reveal aspects of your world-building. For example, a character's backstory might reveal the history of a particular region or the culture of a certain group of people.

By following these tips and using Ulysses to organize your character development, you'll be well on your way to creating a rich and immersive story that will captivate your readers.

Good luck, and have fun developing your characters!
